In the Iron and Steel industries it is satis-factory to note that there was again a further improvement during the month. So far very few blast furnaces have been re-kindled, but a considerable number of steel furnaces have been re-started, mostly in the Midlands. In the North-Eastern area and in Lanarkshire the recovery from the disorganisation caused by the strike has been slower, but the outlook towards the end of the month was much more pi-omising. Although not appearing on the above table, the Shipbuilding industry showed a slight decrease in unemployment during the month (1,591), and, from the amount of orders which are reported to have accumulated, considerable activity is likely to take place in most areas as soon as normal supplies of fuel and steel become available. The anticipated recovery in the Cotton industry did not make itself manifest during the month, largely owing, it is said, to instability in the prices of the raw material. Such improvement as did take place was due to the resumption of full-time workiug in certain areas in the American spinning section contrary to the recommendations of the Short Time Organisation Com-mittee. In the Woollen and Worsted and in the Boot and Shoe trades the improvement which took place can largely be attributed to seasonal causes. Increased activity, also pai*tly of a seasonal nature, was maintained in the Motor industry.The principal increases in unemployment during the month were in the Building, General Engineering and in the other industries mentioned in the above table. A geographical analysis shows that these increases were confined largely to the South-Eastern and South-Western Divisions, the numbers on the Registers of these two Divisions showing a total increase of approximately 23,400 during the month. With regard to the increase in unemployment which is shown in the latter Division (15,500), it is necessary to explain that 75 per cent, of this has been caused by a slackening in one particular area, namely, Swindon, where over 10,000 employees at the Great Western Railway Works were put on short-time working. It is reported that about 50 per cent, of these are expected to resume full-time working in the near future. In Building, the normal seasonal slackness has been accentuated this year by a falling-off in constructional work, largely owing to a shortage of steel supplies. It would appear that this cause has also been responsible for the falling-off in employment in General Engineering.
